canonical_explanation.text: Everything around us that has mass and occupies space is called matter. Matter exists in three states: solid, liquid, and gas. Solids have a definite shape and volume (e.g., stone, book). Liquids have a definite volume but take the shape of the container (e.g., water, milk). Gases have no definite shape or volume and fill the entire container (e.g., air, oxygen). Matter can change from one state to another: melting (solid to liquid), freezing (liquid to solid), evaporation (liquid to gas), and condensation (gas to liquid). Changes in matter are of two types: physical changes are reversible and no new substance is formed (e.g., ice melting), and chemical changes are usually irreversible and a new substance is formed (e.g., burning paper, rusting). The water cycle shows how water moves through different states in nature: evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and collection.
rules: Matter: anything that has mass and occupies space
Three states: solid (definite shape and volume), liquid (definite volume, no definite shape), gas (no definite shape or volume)
Melting: solid to liquid (ice to water)
Freezing: liquid to solid (water to ice)
Evaporation: liquid to gas (water to water vapour)
Condensation: gas to liquid (water vapour to water droplets)
Physical change: reversible, no new substance (e.g., ice melting, dissolving sugar)
Chemical change: usually irreversible, new substance formed (e.g., burning, rusting, cooking)
Water cycle: evaporation → condensation → precipitation → collection
Particles are closely packed in solids, loosely packed in liquids, far apart in gases

questions.question_text: How many states of matter are there?
questions.explanation_correct: There are three states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas. Everything around us exists in one of these three states. For example, ice is a solid, water is a liquid, and steam is a gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At the Class 5 level, we study three states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas. All matter around us exists in one of these three forms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a solid?
questions.explanation_correct: A stone is a solid. It has a definite shape and a definite volume. You cannot pour a stone or compress it easily. Water and milk are liquids, and air is a gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water and milk are liquids (they flow and take the shape of the container). Air is a gas. A stone is a solid because it has a fixed shape and volume.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a gas?
questions.explanation_correct: Oxygen is a gas. It has no definite shape or volume and fills the entire space available. We cannot see oxygen, but it is all around us in the air we breathe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ice and sand are solids, and juice is a liquid. Oxygen is a gas that we breathe in. It has no fixed shape or volume.

questions.question_text: Air is an example of matter in the gaseous state.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Air is a gas (actually a mixture of gases like nitrogen and oxygen). It has no definite shape or volume and fills whatever space is available.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Air is indeed matter in the gaseous state. Although we cannot see air, it has mass and takes up space, which means it is matter.

questions.question_text: Sita pours juice from a bottle into a glass. The juice changes its shape but not its amount. What state of matter is juice?
questions.explanation_correct: Juice is a liquid. Liquids have a definite volume (the amount stays the same) but no definite shape (they take the shape of whatever container they are poured into).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solids keep their shape, and gases spread to fill the entire space. Since juice takes the shape of the glass but keeps the same volume, it is a liquid.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a property of solids?

options.text: They have a definite shape and volume

questions.explanation_correct: Solids have a definite (fixed) shape and a definite volume. They do not change shape when placed in different containers. For example, a book remains the same shape no matter where you put it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flowing easily is a property of liquids. Filling the entire container is a property of gases. Not all solids are transparent. The defining property of solids is their fixed shape and volume.

questions.question_text: Liquids take the shape of the container because:

options.text: Their particles are very tightly packed
Their particles are loosely packed and can move around
Their particles are very far apart

questions.explanation_correct: Liquid particles are loosely packed and can slide past each other. This allows liquids to flow and take the shape of their container while still maintaining a fixed volume.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tightly packed particles are in solids. Very far apart particles are in gases. Liquids have particles that are close but can move around, allowing them to flow and take the shape of the container.

questions.question_text: Why can gases be compressed (squeezed) more easily than solids or liquids?

options.text: Because gas particles are very heavy
Because gas particles are far apart with lots of space between them
Because gases are heavier than solids

questions.explanation_correct: Gas particles are very far apart from each other with lots of empty space between them. When we compress a gas, the particles are pushed closer together into this empty space. Solid and liquid particles are already close together, so they cannot be compressed much.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All matter has particles. Gas particles are not heavier. The reason gases can be compressed is that their particles are far apart with lots of empty space, which can be reduced when pressure is applied.

questions.question_text: Compare the arrangement of particles in the three states of matter. Which is correct?

options.text: Solid: far apart; Liquid: very close; Gas: close
Solid: very close and fixed; Liquid: close but can move; Gas: far apart and free
Solid: free; Liquid: fixed; Gas: close
All three have the same arrangement

questions.explanation_correct: In solids, particles are very close and fixed in position (vibrate but don't move). In liquids, particles are close but can slide around each other. In gases, particles are far apart and move freely in all directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is: Solids have tightly packed, fixed particles. Liquids have close but movable particles. Gases have widely spaced, freely moving particles. This explains the different properties of each state.

questions.question_text: When ice melts, it changes from:
questions.explanation_correct: When ice melts, it changes from solid to liquid. Ice (solid water) absorbs heat from the surroundings and changes into liquid water. This process is called melting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting is always the change from solid to liquid. Gas to liquid is condensation, liquid to solid is freezing, and liquid to gas is evaporation. Ice changing to water is a solid-to-liquid change.

questions.question_text: When water is cooled to 0 degrees Celsius, it becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When water is cooled to 0 degrees Celsius, it freezes and becomes ice. This change from liquid to solid is called freezing. Water freezes at 0 degrees Celsius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Steam and water vapour are formed when water is heated, not cooled. Juice is a different substance. When water is cooled sufficiently (to 0 degrees Celsius), it freezes into ice.

questions.question_text: The process of a liquid changing into a gas is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is the process of a liquid changing into a gas. For example, when wet clothes dry in the sun, the water evaporates (turns into water vapour) and goes into the air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting is solid to liquid. Freezing is liquid to solid. Condensation is gas to liquid. Evaporation is specifically the change from liquid to gas.

questions.question_text: When water vapour in the air cools down and forms water droplets on a cold glass, this is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Condensation is the process of gas (water vapour) changing into liquid (water droplets). When warm, moist air touches the cold glass surface, the water vapour cools down and forms tiny water droplets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation is liquid to gas (the opposite). Melting is solid to liquid. Freezing is liquid to solid. Condensation is specifically the change from gas to liquid.

questions.question_text: Radha hangs wet clothes on the clothesline. After a few hours, the clothes are dry. What happened to the water?

options.text: The water evaporated and turned into water vapour in the air
The clothes absorbed all the water

questions.explanation_correct: The water in the wet clothes evaporated - it changed from liquid water to water vapour (gas) and went into the air. The sun's heat and wind speed up evaporation, which is why clothes dry faster on sunny, windy days.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water does not disappear or get fully absorbed by clothes. It evaporates, changing from liquid to gas. The water molecules escape into the air as water vapour, making the clothes dry.

questions.question_text: In the morning, Arjun sees tiny water droplets on the grass. Where did this water come from?

options.text: Someone poured water on the grass
Water vapour in the air condensed on the cool grass during the night

questions.explanation_correct: The water droplets on grass in the morning are called dew. At night, the temperature drops and the grass becomes cool. Water vapour in the air condenses (turns from gas to liquid) on the cool grass surface, forming tiny water droplets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nobody poured water and grass does not cry. The droplets are dew, formed by condensation. At night, the grass cools down and water vapour in the surrounding air condenses on the cool surface.

questions.question_text:
Match the changes of state:
(i) Melting - (a) Gas to liquid
(ii) Evaporation - (b) Solid to liquid
(iii) Condensation - (c) Liquid to gas
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: Melting is solid to liquid (b), Evaporation is liquid to gas (c), and Condensation is gas to liquid (a). Remember: Melting makes things liquid, Evaporation sends things into the air, Condensation brings them back down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Melting = solid to liquid (ice melting), Evaporation = liquid to gas (water drying up), Condensation = gas to liquid (fog on mirror). The correct matching is (i)-b, (ii)-c, (iii)-a.

questions.question_text: A change where no new substance is formed and is reversible is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A physical change is one where no new substance is formed and the change can usually be reversed. For example, ice melting into water is a physical change because the water can be frozen back into ice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A chemical change creates a new substance and is usually irreversible. A physical change is the one where the substance remains the same and the change can be reversed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a physical change?
questions.explanation_correct: Ice melting into water is a physical change because no new substance is formed (water and ice are both H2O) and the change is reversible (water can be frozen back into ice).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning paper creates ash (new substance), rusting creates iron oxide (new substance), and cooking changes food permanently. Ice melting is a physical change because ice and water are the same substance and the change can be reversed.

questions.question_text: A chemical change is one where:

options.text: A new substance is formed and the change is usually irreversible
The change can always be reversed

questions.explanation_correct: In a chemical change, a new substance is formed with different properties, and the change is usually irreversible (cannot be undone). For example, when wood burns, it turns into ash and smoke - you cannot get wood back from ash.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A physical change is when no new substance is formed and it can be reversed. A chemical change creates entirely new substances and usually cannot be undone.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a chemical change?
questions.explanation_correct: Burning wood is a chemical change because a new substance (ash and carbon dioxide) is formed and the change cannot be reversed. You cannot get wood back from ash and smoke.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dissolving sugar, tearing paper, and breaking glass are physical changes because no new substance is formed. Burning wood produces ash and smoke (new substances), making it a chemical change.

questions.question_text: Neha dissolves sugar in water to make shikanji (lemonade). Is this a physical change or a chemical change?

options.text: Chemical change, because the sugar disappears
Physical change, because the sugar can be recovered by evaporating the water
It is neither a physical nor chemical change
Chemical change, because the water changes colour

questions.explanation_correct: Dissolving sugar in water is a physical change. The sugar does not form a new substance - it is still sugar, just dissolved. If we evaporate the water, we can get the sugar back. This makes it a reversible, physical change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sugar has not really disappeared - it has dissolved in the water. Since no new substance is formed and we can get the sugar back by evaporating the water, this is a physical change.

questions.question_text: Vijay's bicycle chain has turned reddish-brown after being left in the rain. What type of change is this?
questions.explanation_correct: This is rusting, which is a chemical change. Iron reacts with moisture and oxygen in the air to form a new substance called rust (iron oxide). Rust cannot be changed back to iron easily, making it an irreversible chemical change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rusting is not just a surface colour change. It is a chemical change where iron reacts with water and oxygen to form a completely new substance (rust/iron oxide). This change cannot be reversed.

questions.question_text: When Asha's mother cooks an egg, the raw egg changes into a cooked egg. Can she change the cooked egg back into a raw egg?

options.text: No, cooking is a chemical change that cannot be reversed
Yes, by putting it in the fridge

questions.explanation_correct: Cooking an egg is a chemical change. The heat causes new substances to form (the proteins change permanently). A cooked egg cannot be turned back into a raw egg, no matter what we do. This is why chemical changes are called irreversible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cooling, adding water, or refrigerating cannot change a cooked egg back to raw. Cooking involves chemical changes that permanently alter the proteins in the egg. It is an irreversible change.

questions.question_text: Tearing a piece of paper is a chemical change.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Tearing paper is a physical change because no new substance is formed. The torn pieces are still paper. Only the size and shape have changed. Burning paper, however, would be a chemical change because it produces ash and smoke.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Tearing paper only changes the size and shape of the paper. The material is still paper, and no new substance is formed. Therefore, it is a physical change, not a chemical change.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following correctly groups physical and chemical changes?
Physical: ice melting, dissolving salt
Chemical: burning wood, rusting iron

options.text: Only the physical group is correct
Only the chemical group is correct

questions.explanation_correct: Both groups are correct. Ice melting and dissolving salt are physical changes (no new substance, reversible). Burning wood and rusting iron are chemical changes (new substances formed, irreversible).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both groupings are accurate. Ice melting and dissolving salt are physical changes because they are reversible and no new substance is formed. Burning wood (creates ash) and rusting iron (creates iron oxide) are chemical changes.

questions.question_text: The continuous movement of water between the Earth's surface and the atmosphere is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The water cycle is the continuous movement of water between the Earth's surface and the atmosphere through evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and collection. It ensures that water is constantly recycled on Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food chains show energy flow in ecosystems, life cycles show stages of living things, and rock cycles show changes in rocks. The water cycle specifically describes how water moves and changes state between Earth and the sky.

questions.question_text: In the water cycle, what happens first when the sun heats water in rivers and oceans?
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is the first step. When the sun heats water in rivers, lakes, and oceans, the water turns into water vapour (gas) and rises into the atmosphere. This is evaporation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The water cycle begins with evaporation. The sun's heat turns water from rivers, lakes, and oceans into water vapour that rises into the air. After that comes condensation, then precipitation, and finally collection.

questions.question_text: When water vapour rises high in the atmosphere and cools, it forms clouds. This process is:
questions.explanation_correct: Condensation is the process where water vapour cools and forms tiny water droplets. These droplets come together to form clouds. Condensation happens when warm, moist air rises to cooler heights.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation is water becoming vapour. Precipitation is water falling from clouds. Melting is solid to liquid. Condensation is the specific process where water vapour forms water droplets that make up clouds.

questions.question_text: Rain, snow, and hail falling from clouds to the ground is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Precipitation is the falling of water from clouds to the Earth's surface in the form of rain, snow, sleet, or hail. It happens when cloud droplets become too heavy and fall due to gravity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation is water turning to vapour. Condensation forms clouds. Transpiration is water loss from plants. Precipitation is specifically the falling of water from clouds as rain, snow, or hail.

questions.question_text: The correct order of steps in the water cycle is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Evaporation (water turns to vapour) → Condensation (vapour forms clouds) → Precipitation (rain/snow falls from clouds) → Collection (water collects in rivers, lakes, oceans) and the cycle repeats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The water cycle always follows this order: first water evaporates, then the vapour condenses to form clouds, then precipitation falls from clouds, and finally water is collected in water bodies. Then it starts again.

questions.question_text: During the monsoon season in India, it rains heavily. In terms of the water cycle, what process causes the rain?
questions.explanation_correct: Rain is a form of precipitation. During the monsoon, moisture-laden clouds from the oceans move over India, and the water droplets in the clouds fall as rain (precipitation). Evaporation and condensation happened earlier to form these rain clouds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While evaporation and condensation occur before rain, the actual falling of rain from clouds is called precipitation. During the Indian monsoon, large amounts of precipitation occur due to moisture-laden winds from the sea.

questions.question_text: Why is the water cycle important for life on Earth?

options.text: It ensures that fresh water is available again and again through continuous recycling

questions.explanation_correct: The water cycle is important because it continuously recycles water on Earth. The same water evaporates, forms clouds, falls as rain, and collects in rivers and oceans again. This ensures a constant supply of fresh water for all living things.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The water cycle does not create new water or make the sky blue. Its importance is that it recycles the same water over and over, providing fresh water for drinking, farming, and all life processes.

questions.question_text: The three states of matter are solid, liquid, and _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The three states of matter are solid, liquid, and gas. Examples: ice (solid), water (liquid), and steam/air (gas).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While vapour and steam are gaseous forms of water, the general term for the third state of matter is 'gas.' The three states are solid, liquid, and gas.

questions.question_text: The change from liquid to solid is called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Freezing is the change from liquid to solid. When water is cooled to 0 degrees Celsius, it freezes and becomes ice. The liquid loses heat energy and its particles slow down, forming a solid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting is solid to liquid, evaporation is liquid to gas, and condensation is gas to liquid. Freezing is specifically the change from liquid to solid.

questions.question_text: Which property is common to both liquids and gases but NOT solids?
questions.explanation_correct: Both liquids and gases can flow (they are called fluids). Solids cannot flow. Liquids and gases take the shape of their container because their particles can move past each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solids have a definite shape, not liquids or gases. Only liquids have a definite volume (gases do not). Both liquids and gases share the ability to flow, which is why they are collectively called fluids.

questions.question_text: Cooking rice is a _____ change, while dissolving salt in water is a _____ change.
questions.explanation_correct: Cooking rice is a chemical change because the raw rice changes permanently (you cannot get raw rice back from cooked rice). Dissolving salt in water is a physical change because the salt can be recovered by evaporating the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cooking involves heat that permanently changes the food (chemical change). Dissolving salt just mixes it with water without forming a new substance, and the salt can be recovered (physical change).

questions.question_text: Suresh blows air into a balloon. The balloon expands. This shows that air:
questions.explanation_correct: When air is blown into a balloon, it expands because the air takes up space inside. This proves that air occupies space (has volume), which is one of the properties of matter. Air is matter in the gaseous state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The balloon expanding proves that air takes up space. Air has mass and is matter (in the gas state). It is not a liquid. The expansion of the balloon shows that gases occupy space.

questions.question_text: Water can exist as ice, liquid water, and steam. What causes water to change from one state to another?
questions.explanation_correct: Adding or removing heat energy causes water to change state. Adding heat melts ice (solid to liquid) and evaporates water (liquid to gas). Removing heat freezes water (liquid to solid) and condenses steam (gas to liquid).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salt, sugar, and shaking do not cause changes of state. It is heat energy that causes state changes. Adding heat converts ice to water to steam, and removing heat reverses these changes.

questions.question_text: Burning a candle is a physical change because the wax melts.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. While the wax melting is a physical change, burning a candle overall is a chemical change. The burning produces new substances like carbon dioxide and water vapour. The wax cannot be recovered from the smoke and gases produced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Burning involves a chemical reaction that produces new substances (carbon dioxide, water vapour, soot). While wax melting is physical, the overall burning process is a chemical change.

questions.question_text: Classify the following: (i) Folding paper (ii) Burning paper (iii) Cutting a fruit (iv) Fruit rotting

options.text: (i) and (iii) are physical; (ii) and (iv) are chemical
(i) and (ii) are physical; (iii) and (iv) are chemical

questions.explanation_correct: Folding paper and cutting a fruit are physical changes (no new substance formed, only shape/size changes). Burning paper and fruit rotting are chemical changes (new substances are formed and the changes are irreversible).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Folding and cutting only change shape/size without creating new substances (physical changes). Burning creates ash and smoke (chemical change), and rotting involves decomposition creating new substances (chemical change).

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Wet clothes dry faster on a sunny, windy day.
Reason: Heat and wind speed up evaporation.
Choose the correct option.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion
The assertion is true but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason explains the assertion. Wet clothes dry faster on sunny, windy days because the sun's heat increases the rate of evaporation and wind carries away the water vapour, allowing more water to evaporate quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true (clothes do dry faster on sunny, windy days) and the reason is also true (heat and wind speed up evaporation). The reason correctly explains why the clothes dry faster.

questions.question_text: A perfume bottle is opened in one corner of a room. Soon, the fragrance can be smelled throughout the room. What does this tell us about gases?

options.text: Gas particles move freely and spread in all directions

questions.explanation_correct: The fragrance spreading shows that gas particles move freely in all directions. Perfume molecules evaporate and spread throughout the room because gas particles have lots of energy and move rapidly, filling all available space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The spreading of perfume fragrance throughout a room demonstrates that gas particles are constantly moving in all directions. This property is called diffusion and shows that gases spread to fill any available space.

questions.question_text: Rina takes ice cream out of the freezer. After 10 minutes, it starts to melt. After 30 minutes in the hot sun, it becomes a liquid puddle. What changes of state occurred?

options.text: Melting (solid ice cream changed to liquid)

questions.explanation_correct: The ice cream underwent melting - it changed from a frozen solid to a liquid. The heat from the surroundings caused the solid ice cream to melt into a liquid puddle. This is a solid-to-liquid change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Freezing is liquid to solid (the opposite). Condensation is gas to liquid. Evaporation is liquid to gas. The ice cream underwent melting, changing from solid to liquid due to heat.

questions.question_text: Rusting of iron is a _____ change because a new substance (rust) is formed.
questions.explanation_correct: Rusting is a chemical change because a new substance (iron oxide/rust) is formed when iron reacts with water and oxygen. The rust has different properties from iron, and the change cannot be easily reversed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rusting is not physical, temporary, or reversible. It is a chemical change because iron combines with oxygen and water to form an entirely new substance (rust) with different properties.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a property of matter?
questions.explanation_correct: Not all matter can be seen. Air is matter (it has mass and takes up space) but we cannot see it. Many gases are invisible. Matter does have mass, occupies space, and exists in three states, but it is not always visible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Matter has mass, occupies space, and exists in three states - these are all correct properties. But the statement 'it can always be seen' is false because gases like air and oxygen are invisible.

questions.question_text: A farmer in Rajasthan uses a matka (clay pot) to keep water cool in summer. How does this work?

options.text: The clay adds ice to the water
Water seeps through tiny pores in the clay and evaporates, cooling the remaining water
The matka has a fridge inside
The clay absorbs all the heat

questions.explanation_correct: The clay pot has tiny pores through which water slowly seeps to the surface. This water evaporates from the surface, and evaporation is a cooling process (it takes heat from the remaining water). This makes the water inside cooler.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The matka works on the principle of evaporation. Water seeps through the porous clay to the outside surface and evaporates. Since evaporation uses heat energy, it takes heat from the water inside, making it cool.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a sign that a chemical change has occurred?

options.text: Change in colour, smell, or production of gas, heat, or new substance

questions.explanation_correct: Signs of a chemical change include change in colour, change in smell, production of gas (bubbles), release or absorption of heat, or formation of a new substance. For example, burning produces heat, light, and a colour change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Changes in shape, size, or position are signs of physical changes. Chemical changes are indicated by the formation of new substances, which can be detected by colour change, odour change, gas production, or energy changes.

questions.question_text: The water cycle creates new water on Earth.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The water cycle does NOT create new water. It recycles the same water that has existed on Earth for millions of years. Water changes form (liquid, solid, gas) and location, but the total amount of water on Earth remains the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. The water cycle recycles existing water through evaporation, condensation, and precipitation. No new water is created. The water on Earth today is the same water that has been cycling for billions of years.

questions.question_text: Why does a sponge absorb water even though it is a solid?

options.text: Because sponge is actually a liquid
Because the sponge has tiny holes (pores) that trap and hold water

questions.explanation_correct: A sponge is a solid with many tiny holes (pores). Water fills these holes when the sponge is placed in water. The sponge is still a solid - it is the porous structure that allows it to hold water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sponge is indeed a solid, and not all solids absorb water. The sponge absorbs water because of its unique structure with many tiny pores that can trap and hold water inside.

questions.question_text: Water at 100 degrees Celsius starts boiling and turns to steam. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: When water boils at 100 degrees Celsius and turns to steam, it changes from liquid to gas. Boiling is a rapid form of evaporation that occurs at a specific temperature (100 degrees Celsius for water).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting is solid to liquid, freezing is liquid to solid, and condensation is gas to liquid. Boiling is the change from liquid to gas at a specific temperature, which is a form of evaporation.
